meanings.definition: To treat as a cat; to bring up or rear as a cat.
meanings.sent1: She catted the stray kitten, feeding it milk and cuddling it.
meanings.sent2: The family catted their pet, giving it a cozy bed and toys to play with.
meanings.sent3: He catted his friend by playfully pretending to purr and chase a toy mouse.
meanings.sent4: The teacher catted the students, guiding them with gentle care and patience.
meanings.sent5: The kind lady catted the injured bird, nursing it back to health with love and attention.

meanings.sent1: The cat catted five adorable kittens in a cozy corner of the barn.
meanings.sent2: The stray cat catted a litter of kittens under the porch of the old house.
meanings.sent3: The cat catted so many kittens that the whole neighborhood was filled with meowing.
meanings.sent4: The mama cat catted her kittens with pride, watching them play and explore.
meanings.sent5: The cat catted a surprise litter of kittens, surprising everyone with their cuteness.

meanings.definition: To hoist (an anchor) and secure it at the cathead.
meanings.sent1: The sailors catted the anchor swiftly, readying the ship for departure.
meanings.sent2: They catted the heavy anchor with teamwork, pulling it up to the cathead.
meanings.sent3: The crew catted the anchor while singing a sea shanty, making the task more enjoyable.
meanings.sent4: The captain catted the anchor skillfully, ensuring the ship was secure for the night.
meanings.sent5: With a heave-ho, they catted the anchor to the cathead, preparing to set sail.
